blocks.data: Measurements on Magento Cloud Infrastructure - B2C
<w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/><w:br/>Helix Team<w:br/>Cloud, Performance & Measurements

This white paper contains results of performance measurements of Magento Commerce 2.2.6 running on Magento Cloud Pro infrastructure for cases of Small, Medium and Large profiles. Measurements track response rates captured for high-loaded eCommerce sites on Magento Cloud Pro production environments 12 to 120.<w:br/><w:br/>All performance measurements are based on simulated day-to-day store activities for customers and business users. The values is also reflect a maximum throughout for each case, but don't reflect unique business models, like private sales or flash sales.<w:br/><w:br/>This information aids eCommerce managers and technical staff to better understand the performance characteristics of the application and select an appropriate plan for Magento Commerce store using Magento Cloud environments and services.<w:br/><w:br/>When considering Magento Cloud for your Magento Commerce storefronts, review Instance Profile Configuration to determine which profile meets the size of your storefront. All performance results in this white paper are titled by profile and environment size.

Magento Commerce (Cloud) environments PRO12 and PRO24 with Small and Medium profiles can serve described load without any specific customizations and demonstrate above response time results for day-to-day store activities and sales.<li>Magento Commerce (Cloud) environments for PRO48 and PRO120 with Large profile require customizations in Magento code/infrastructure.<li>Client-side performance tests demonstrated good results.<li>Full indexation for Large profile takes a significant amount of time.<li>Emulating real instances, 0% cache hit rate was used during the measurements that implies more time of response caused by request to application and subsequent processes.

The scenarios use the following data profiles. Each data profile includes a number of sites, products, and categories matching stores typically considered small, medium, large, and extra-large B2C installations.<w:br/><w:br/>All profiles are available through the Magento 2 GitHub repository, Profiles.<w:br/>

rows.text: * Websites/stores/stores view: 1 (total)<w:br/>* Individual simple products: 800<w:br/>* Configurable products: 40(with 15 simple products for each configurable product, ~ 600 simple products)<w:br/>* Categories: 30<w:br/>* Customers: 200

* Websites/stores/stores view: 3 (total)<w:br/>Individual simple products: 24,000<w:br/>* Configurable products: 640(with 11 simple products for each configurable product, ~ 7,000 simple products)<w:br/>* Categories: 300<w:br/>* Customers: 2,000

* Websites/stores/stores view: 5 (total)<w:br/>* Individual simple products: 300,000<w:br/>* Configurable products: 8,000(with 11 simple products for each configurable product, ~ 88,000 simple products)<w:br/>* Categories: 3,000<w:br/>* Customers: 5,000

blocks.data: Note: you can find test data generation tools and the data profile configuration in https://github.com/magento/magento2/tree/2.2.5/setup/performance-toolkit.
Every experiment uses the profiles listed in Instance Profile Configuration. These experiments use the following parameters.

Cache hit/miss rate: 0% hit, means that with avg cache hit ratio (~80%) the load could be up to 5 times larger while achieving same performance
  • User actions: Each user performs 2-3 actions (clicks) per minute. The average industry rate is 1 click per 1-2 minutes. Actions tested include
  • Load average: 1 user per core
  • Storefront Frontend and Magento Admin actions: Performance of actions completed by customers and business users managing the storefront
  • Site Performance Tools: Performance according to sitespeed.io
Load average: starting from 0.25x users per core to 8x users per core of the application server
We capture data through the experiments for the 90 percentile and additionaly mediana for main table with response time.
Note: the traffic profiles represent an average b2c scenario. For specific use cases like marketplace, flash sales, b2b, single product sites etc, the numbers might be significantly different.
For detailed information on our available Magento Commerce (Cloud) plans and options, see our site for plan information and DevDocs content.

blocks.title: Cloud infrastructure schema
blocks.data: Experiments run through JMeter using profiles against the Magento Cloud Pro environment. The following image details the entry point of JMeter and Production infrastructure. For additional information, see the DevDocs Magento Commerce (Cloud) guide – Pro architecture.
/resources/Content/Environment.png

blocks.title: Instances technical information
blocks.data: All tests were run in the Production environment in Magento Commerce (Cloud) Pro plan environments.<w:br/>

To test performance of several areas of the system, the testing simulates user activity by browsing, adding to cart and buying products, among others. Graph below show the distribution of the simulated activity.
This report includes graphs and tables of captured and calculated performance measurements. Each test includes graphs of median performance values and tables with more details.

blocks.title: Reading performance results
blocks.data: Performance Experiment NameThe name of each experiment testing section details the Cloud plan, environment size, and profile of store.For example, the title “Pro12 instance with Small profile benchmarking” indicates:
Pro Cloud Plan – The Pro production environment is a dedicated server<li>12 Environment size<li>Small store profile size

GraphsGraphs map median measurements of performance tests for specific requests and responses. Each graph has a title for the test, legend for the tracked data, and 90 percentile of response time values. For detailed information with numbers see the corresponding tables below the graphs.

How to interpret the graphsThe graphs show page load time (or whatever) depends on the number of traffic generating threads. When the page load time becomes unacceptable (we assume 2 seconds), you can deduct the maximum number of concurrent users the system could handle without caching.

TablesThe tables provide compiled, exact values of mediana and 90 percentiles for each of the graphs and additional collected data from tests. Values are calculated from server time (including HTTP request) but exclude loading any resources (images, scripts, style sheets).All values are color-coded according to benchmarks:
Green – Within benchmarks (<2 sec page load time)<li>Orange – Exceeding benchmarks(>2 sec, < 3 sec )<li>Red – Significantly exceeding benchmark

blocks.title: Performance tests performed
blocks.data: Three performance tests are performed for all experiments to determine performance: benchmarking, API, and client-side. All tests are available through the Magento 2 GitHub repository, the Performance Toolkit.
Benchmarking testsAll values are rated against the following benchmarks:
Server-side response, multi-thread<w:br/>
Storefront: non-cached 2 sec, cached 500 ms<li>Admin: non-cached 4 sec

Client-side performanceAll client-side tests are single-thread. The experiment initiates actions through the storefront site as if performed by customers. The performance tests capture reports and data from these tools profiling stores using the test profile and target Magento Cloud Infrastructure.
